column4: Well i was thinking more of copying them if they were missing
type "sudo modprobe <driver name>"
in the terminal, of course
I was going to try that but wasn't sure what the module was
I use the wl broadcom driver, so sudo modprobe wl usually does it for me... you can "locate bcm | grep /lib/modules" to see what other bcm drivers there are :/
I wonder why the system claims to be 'downloading' it when it handles prop drivers?
(As if it really did, locate would fail)
hm... It must be trying all over then. BTW, make sure your Wifi's switch is on.
how come?
Because the locate database wouldn't have been updated since the 'download'
sudo updatedb then ;)
I wonder how it downloads without a network connection though ? ;)
I wonder how you want them to work without having them installed. Or am I missing something?
Usually you plug in a wired LAN, let it take care of that, and then see if the drivers work
that *can* work, but it may take you a while to get all of the dependencies right.

Yes. It would just be a way around no network problem. I'm guessing that the 'downloading' thing is false and that they're really in the ramdisk. If so, i'll try modprobing it, though i'm surprised about the 'system requires restart' business. But of course there could be firmware issues too...
system requires restart is an easy way of telling someone to modprobe :)
the kernel loads modules upon modprobe or restart.
>>is an easy way of telling someone to modprobe Yes - slightly too dumbed down perhaps? ;)

no not really. From a design point of view, it's the best thing ever. Telling your normal office worker to open a terminal and write "sudo modprobe" is too difficult. Making a script that does that is too risky.
Maybe, yes.
get a connection because you cannot download drivers without any internet
But this is where we came in ;) They must be already there as the system 'downloaded' them with no net connection - or did it?
texas ^^
